title: Salt on the Tongue
description: Brinelaw Keep rose like a salt-brick reef from the old tide-channel, its slabs damp with the breath of the sea and its tide-clock lifting a silver tongue of water in a windowed shaft. Within, the Oathwell cupped winter in a ring of worked bone, steamless and stern, ready to bite any mouth that dared bring falsehood near. High Bailiff Osric Greyfen summoned Mara across floors carved with the twelve stones of Brinelaw, and the city’s murmurs seemed to hush as marrow-light pooled across his bench, the light steady as a verdict. Word had drifted to his ears of a shard that sang in the Tidemill Array and of a hum that brushed Dorsalhaven’s sleep like a passing fin beneath the keel, a strange consonance with rumors of counterfeit Tideglass passes moving through the Market of Teeth in a way that made honest ledgers blink. Ketta Brineshaw, tide-scribe and winter-eyed, waited with ledgers and seals and a seized salt-glass pass that held a thumbprint in its cool heart, a whorl trapped like a fish in clear ice; the choice before Mara gleamed like a knife in moonlight: swear the brine and thread the lawful channels until they stung, or let shadows breathe long enough to snare their own smoke without snapping the city’s chains.
objectives: Drink from the Oathwell to swear a limited investigator’s oath under Brinelaw, letting the winter-brine sting your tongue as a promise sharper than steel.
Examine the seized salt-glass pass and ledgers with Ketta Brineshaw for connections to the Array’s strange hum and the counterfeit routes that drift toward the Tideglass Flats.
Interview a Ribshadow contact at the Market of Teeth without provoking a Brinelaw clash, gathering truths with care so the stalls do not splinter and the oath-bells do not ring.
Deliver a preliminary report to Osric Greyfen and request a standing writ for further inquiries, setting the next steps in ink that even the tide must respect.

dialogue.speaker: Osric Greyfen
dialogue.lines: Brine strips flattery from the mouth, and so I will not offer you any, Mara Kestrel. Dorsalhaven rides a skeleton chained to the seabed by good sense and bad memory, and it falls to my bench to remember which is which when the wind begins to lie. If the Array is touched by sabotage, I must cut out the rot before it spreads, for I have seen iron scythe a dock and I will not hear that song again. If it is touched by myth, I must make room for faith without letting it capsize the law, because we are a city that kneels to both tide and text and we drown when we pretend otherwise. Swear to me in salt that what you bring back will be true enough to survive the Oathwell’s memory, for the Well keeps what we try to forget. Know also that the counterfeiters who ply the Flats gnaw at the same chain that keeps the jaw-harbor safe, and every easy pass is a cut we do not see until the storm. Take this writ, sharp as a needle and just as small, and use it to prick secrets without drawing a gaol-sentence, but do not mistake it for armor. If you lie to me, the Well will taste it, and if you tell me a hard truth, I will shoulder it even if it drags my name through kelp and grit.

dialogue.speaker: Ketta Brineshaw
dialogue.lines: The pass we seized is clever work, better than the usual jaw-hinge counterfeits, and it shamed me a little to admire it while I logged it into evidence. The thumbprint frozen inside is smudged just so, as if the owner wanted to be seen but not held, a flirtation with exposure that suggests they trust their swimmers’ lungs. Whoever made this knew our inks, our drying sands, and the way our bailiffs sweat on their rounds, because the sweat marks we rely on for timing were faked with salt-mist blown through reed cloth. If we follow the lines in the glass, they lead to the Flats, to the Market, and to someone who understands both ledgers and lulls, a hand that knows when patrol routes thin like gruel near the oath-bells. The Array’s hum you asked about leaves a faint ripple in the halite grits we keep for calibration, and I can show you the grains that trembled when the tide-clock did not. Walk with me through the ledgers, and I will mark the places where the numbers cough, then we will take our Oathwell phials and see which seals curdle when tasted, for salt remembers the shape of a lie even when the ink pretends it does not.

dialogue.speaker: Neth Cowl
dialogue.lines: Careful where you dip your cup, Kestrel, because the Oathwell bites harder than the sea when you taste it too often and it makes a habit out of pain. Ask me a straight question and I will give you a straight answer with a bend in it, because the world is crooked and yet it floats: the forged passes keep fisher families fed when tariffs gnaw to the bone and the Compact forgets to count mouths. The Array’s hum is not ours, and I would carve that into the side of my skiff if carving did not slow a boat; we prefer chains that sing true, because we dance on them at night and a bad note makes a widow before dawn. You want the names of my pass-pressers, but I want the city to remember that a chain is a covenant, not just a shackle, and covenants break when only one side eats. Meet me under the jaw’s sixth tooth when the marrow-lamps turn blue, and I will show you where a clerk sells more than parchment and a lamplighter carries more than fuel; but if you bring bailiffs, you bring a storm, and storms wash away the small boats first. If you must carry the law in your mouth, carry it like a blade wrapped in cloth; it cuts cleaner when you do not wave it around and people keep their fingers when your hand is steady.

dialogue.speaker: Mara Kestrel
dialogue.lines: I will drink the brine and let it burn, Osric, because I have learned that a clean sting now is kinder than rot later. I will read your ledgers, Ketta, and I will ask my questions in the Market without breaking the stalls, because a truth shouted at the wrong hour becomes a lie that the city pays for in coin and blood. Captain Cowl, I hear the hunger behind your bravado, and I know the taste of bad winters, but if I find your prints where the law cannot ignore them, I will put the truth on Osric’s bench and let the tide decide because I have stood under chains when they sang wrong. The Array’s hum has been in my bowstring for nights and I do not know if it is sabotage or dreaming, but I intend to find out before someone mistakes a hymn for a warning bell. No one dances if the chain parts, and no mother sleeps when a lantern dies in a winter alley, so I will walk this line between salt and shadow with my eyes open and my mouth honest even when it hurts.

choices.title: Spill the Truth into the Well
choices.text: Mara goes first to the Oathwell and drinks deeply enough that the winter-chill crawls behind her eyes, then she tells Ketta that the thumbprint in the seized pass matches her own, trapped from a bad night when hunger and debt turned her into a courier for shadows. She lays out the shape of that night in five long breaths, naming no families and no children, but owning her route and the way it brushed the Salt Widow’s bluffs like a moth at a lantern. She asks Ketta to bind the confession under a limited investigator’s seal, invoking Brinelaw’s clause for self-incrimination Deferred in the Public Good, and she swears to hunt the forgers who used her past as a shield. She explains that keeping the pass intact will let them follow the counterfeit ink back to the press, and that destroying it will only cut their net and let bigger fish slip off laughing. She ends by saying she will carry the shame on her back like a coil of rope if it means no one else will drown when the next squall rolls in.
choices.outcome: Ketta accepts the brined confession and knots it in her ledger under a clause that makes the page heavy to turn, and she marks the pass for supervised handling so its chain of custody sings true. Osric listens stone-still and then grants the limited writ with a look that promises both protection and scrutiny, and he assigns a single bailiff to trail distant as a shadow so Mara is never completely alone nor completely trusted. The Ribshadow Brotherhood catches wind that Mara spoke, and they flinch away from using her for errands, but Neth Cowl still meets her at the sixth tooth because she did not give up names, only her own. The investigation moves clean, the Oathwell hum behind Mara’s teeth steadies her questions, and doors that would have slammed creak open because the Keepers smell no fresh lies. The risk lingers like salt at the lip of a cup—if the case sours, Osric can pull that old night into daylight—but for now the truth buys time, the writ is hers, and the pass remains a hook baited for the pressman with steady hands.

choices.title: Balance on the Chain Between Law and Night
choices.text: Mara swears at the Oathwell and feels the lawful chill take root, then she goes to the Market of Teeth under her waxed reefcloak and asks Neth Cowl for a dance step that will not break the boards. She proposes a controlled sting: a counterfeit pass traced with Ketta’s forensic salt-ink exchanged at a time and stall of Neth’s choosing, so no fisher family is dragged into the light and only the pressman’s hubris is hooked. She promises Neth that no bailiffs will loom in the main aisle and that the oath-bells will not ring unless a knife is drawn, and she promises Ketta that the ledger will show contact times to the bead so Brinelaw’s chain is not tested. She keeps her own name out of the seized pass by refusing to handle it directly, asking Ketta to work through a scribe-glove and to let the salt-ink do the touching, a compromise that tastes of brine and smoke. She sets the meet under the sixth tooth when marrow-lamps go blue and tells both parties to trust her once, just once, because the city sings a bad note and she needs two choirs to tune it.
choices.outcome: Neth agrees with a half smile and two watchers on the high ropewalks, and Ketta agrees with a hollow swallow and a bailiff hidden in a crowd of chain-yardsmen carrying coils so heavy they look like work not watch. The marked pass changes hands with a quiet scratch of glass on tooth, and the salt-ink tracer catches easily in the pressman’s palm creases, a ghost that glows when kissed with Oathwell brine. Osric receives a preliminary report that reads like a tightrope and frowns at the margins, but the results are hard to deny: a route mapped, a counterfeiter identified, and no stall overturned, so he grudges praise and extends Mara’s writ to the next tide. The Brotherhood grumbles but respects a plan that did not send mothers to Brinelaw’s steps, and a whisper goes out that Mara’s word holds when she binds it with salt. The Array’s hum still troubles the Tidemill logs, but now inked names begin to curve toward the Flats, and the investigation threads forward with both shadow and law forced to keep their balance.

choices.title: Smudge the Past, Save the Present
choices.text: Mara swears at the Oathwell and takes the writ, then excuses herself to Ketta’s side table and studies the seized pass with a hunter’s eye while the tide-scribe checks a ledger in the next alcove. She opens the sealed pouch of forensic salt-ink, breathes a promise into it that no lie will be born of it, and lays a hair-thin veil over the smudged thumbprint, not enough to erase the whorl, just enough to blur the intimacy that could name her. She tells herself that the city’s safety matters more than the old mistake on that glass, and that if the investigation dies on the altar of her shame the forgers will only grow bolder and the Array’s hum will go unanswered. When Ketta returns, Mara points out other features—the reed-cloth sweat, the halite grit, the timing cuts—and steers the talk toward methods not identities, offering to run the Market quietly and keep Brinelaw’s hands clean for this pass at least. She sets her jaw and carries the altered evidence like a hot coal, determined to turn the heat into light before it burns her fingers through.
choices.outcome: Ketta notices that the print reads clean in strange light but cannot place why, and she frowns at the page as if a word she knew suddenly will not pronounce, yet she lets the analysis continue because the other signs sing true. Osric receives a preliminary report that is strong on technique and thin on names, and he issues the standing writ with a warning that his patience is measured like the tide-clock, steady until it drops. The Brotherhood, unaware of the near disaster, opens a door at the Market and points Mara to a clerk who trades in paper and silence, and the investigation advances along ink-slick lanes. But the Oathwell’s taste clings to Mara’s tongue like a question, and she knows that if Ketta later discovers the tampering, Brinelaw’s trust will crack like salt-crust under a careless boot. For now, however, the inquiry lives, the chain holds, and the pass serves its purpose as a lantern in a fog without naming the hand that once carried it into the dark.

rewards.description: Brinelaw investigator’s writ, limited to city infrastructure and counterfeit passes, a needle-small license to prick secrets without drawing a gaol-sentence.
Access to Brinelaw archives with Ketta Brineshaw’s sponsorship, including ledgers, seized seals, and calibration sands touched by the Array’s hum.
Standing with Brinelaw Keepers (Osric Greyfen), the quiet kind that makes doors unlatch and oath-bells hesitate before ringing.
A sealed pouch of forensic salt-ink for revealing tampered seals, its grain whispering truths when kissed with Oathwell brine.
